overview: Students will develop the skills required for music graduates to be able to form careers in music-focused arts organisations or individual enterprises. They will be introduced to a wide range of examples of how careers involving music can be created and sustained, and how they can position themselves to gain employment.

Matters such as governance, funding, copyright law, and programming issues are investigated so that students gain an understanding of arts administration in music, the range of roles available within music-focused arts organisations, and of the issues unique to the music industry. Some key readings in the area will be studied.
intended learning outcomes: reflect upon, articulate and communicate personal objectives and competencies related to establishing a career in music;
think creatively about ways to incorporate musical skills and knowledge into a career;
develop and refine strategies for building and sustaining careers involving music;
follow a well-conceived process in applying for or creating music-related positions;
understand key factors unique to music-focussed arts organisations;
develop skills to be able to critically evaluate issues and challenges faced by music-focussed arts organisations.

assessments.description: EITHER Option 1: Three 500-word brief assignments on issues studied in class - Weeks 5, 8, 11. 1500 words (total)
OR Option 2: A research report on issues studied in class relevant to student's career concept. 1500 words
10-minute Class presentation on career concept and strategies for realisation. 1000 words (equivalent)
Portfolio consisting of a curriculum vitae, career concept/background and career planning document. 2500 words (equivalent)
Hurdle requirement:. Attendance and class participation: 100% attendance is required; less than 80% will result in a fail.

Semester 1.Contact hours: 24 hours, comprising one 2-hour seminar per week

Prescribed texts: Readings will be available via the subject’s LMS website.
